instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
Hello all,

Does anybody know in what order should I check power rails as far as importance. Example, I do not have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Should I just stop there and chase that one down first on this board, or is there another rail I must chase down first then chase down <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. 

On older boards, if I did not have the above rail, all other rails were irrelevant until I figured that out first. But while I'm reading other questions on this board I'm confused about what powers need to be present 1st - 2nd- 3rd etc. in order to get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and etc. Just looking for some kind of flow chart procedure if possible.

I have voltage right now on my usb meter of 5.14v.
I do not have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> at either <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips but do have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.3v at both same chips. 

And on a side note, are there any specific rails NOT to inject voltage on in order to test? 

Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
First of all check diode mode to ground at F7000 and L6960; red probe connected to ground.

Do you get voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 0v
F7000 1.300
L6960 .465

So I take it from the direction this is going <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> would be the first voltage to make sure is there before the others? Like the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was on older boards?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
You must get <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> voltage first.
Looks like input MOSFETs are not controlled by <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Post diode mode at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> .563 diode mode
I now have 5v at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>
Looks like input MOSFETs are not controlled by <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips (what did you mean by that?) Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
VBUS voltage must pass through <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>, or other input MOSFET to arrive at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.
As you didn't get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> (initially), was because input MOSFETs were not correctly controlled.
Any voltage at F7000 now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
Thanks. I went ahead and replaced both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> because there was a little corrosion around both. I now have 20v at usb meter but 0amps.
F7000 shows 12.63v but it cycles down to 0v and then back to 12.63v. it does this continually. I rechecked F7000 in diode mode and now I get OL reading and not the 1.300 I had before replacing the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s. 

I have all my rails except all of the cpu core voltages and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3SSW_SNS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL>.
I chased these all down to all the enables are not working. They all seem to come from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. 

There was a slight amount of corrosion around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> also. I heated it up with some flux to get rid of any water/corrosion under it but still no go.

What things do I need to check as far as voltages on <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> before condemning it bad? Or, am I heading down the wrong direction going after <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> as the fault area?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
Should be better to reball/change <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
If <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is cycling, check for short, or low resistance, on secondary power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
When you say secondary power rails, what rails are those? I checked all the rails on page 121. Is there another page that has the rails you are referring to?
As far as the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, do you know if there is firmware on that chip? Does your store sell those chips?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
Secondary rail is any other voltage than <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, which derives from it; all big coil, for example.
But also voltages derived from a rail generated in base of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, or <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>; like in page 67.

Should be good to take <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> from donor board, to prevent any issue.
Not sure if has board specific firmware, or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message: Great! Where do I get a stencil for <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>? What reballing paste do you recommend?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
You will need universal stencil, I suppose.
Just find one with correct pitch, no matters if bigger.

Any solder paste should be good.
Just be sure to get leaded, 183 degrees.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message: Great! What settings do you use on the hot air station for reballing? Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Macbook Air 2018 No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other Rails
threads.message:
Practice with scrap boards and dead chips.
Settings depend by hot air station.
